_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Urethane and Other Foam Product (except Polystyrene) Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FXI, Inc. takes safety very seriously.  We use safety equipment and strict procedures to prevent releases and to reduce the impact of any release that might occur.  Some examples are:



    -Regular equipment inspections and maintenance to ensure proper operation.

    -Investigation of all incidents to improve our procedures.

    -Secondary containment to ensure that the contents of hazardous material remain on site.

    -Hazardous Waste and Hazardous Materials, Emergency Contingency Planning.

    -Hazardous Materials Awareness Training



EMERGENCY RESPONSE



FXI, Inc. personnel are regularly trained and drilled on safety and accident prevention.  

The following agencies are in place to respond to a release of hazardous material.



    -Baldwyn Volunteer Fire Department 

    -Resource Environmental, Inc.

    -HEPACO, LLC.

    -Mississippi Emergency Management Agency

    - Lee County's HAZWOPER response team of the Tupelo Fire Department



At the FXI, Inc. plant in Baldwyn, MS, we handle toluene diisocyanate (TDI), which is considered hazardous and is regulated by the EPA.  The same properties that make TDI valuable for use at our facility also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in the handling of the substance.  TDI is considered a toxic substance, and associated safety precautions have been implemented to (1) prevent unnecessary human exposure, (2) reduce the threat to the health of our employees at the Baldwyn, MS plant, and (3) reduce the threat to nearby members of our community.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.



We are committed to the safety of our employees and the public, and to the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  Successful implementation of our accidental release prevention program will help ensure that emergencies are unlikely and reduce the likelihood that emergency response procedures will be needed.  Nevertheless, an eme

rgency such as a release of TDI is possible.  We have emergency response procedures to help ensure that accidents will be mitigated properly without undue risk to the public, environment, employees, contractors, or other personnel within the plant.



Description of the facility and the regulated substances handled



The primary purpose of this facility is to produce polyurethane foam, which is sold to other facilities and is used to produce furniture, bedding, carpet padding and a number of other products.  TDI is one of the reactants required to produce our polyurethane foam.  TDI is received by railcar and by tank truck, and is stored in two indoor storage tanks.  The maximum quantity of TDI stored in the process (i.e., in storage tanks and one railcar) at our plant is about 534,000 lb.  The TDI is piped to a mix head where it is mixed with other reactants to produce a slab of polyurethane foam.  The foam products are shipped to customers by truck.



TDI is the only substance handled at our plant that is regulated by EPA's risk management program (RMP) rule.  This substance is covered because the maximum quantity contained in our TDI process exceeds EPA's threshold quantity of 10,000 lb for TDI.





Offsite consequence analysis of release scenarios:



DELETED in Accordance with 4/19/2004 Rulemaking.



The general accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps



The plant has implemented programs and procedures that comply with EPA's Level 1 Accidental Release Prevention Program Rule, which specifies that we notify and coordinate with local emergency planning agencies.



We have coordinated with HEPACO, LLC (contracted professional emergency response firm) and the Prentiss County Development Commission.



 The TDI process at our plant has hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The prevention program outlined above is applied to the TDI process.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent p

otential accidental releases that could be caused by equipment failures, human errors, and management system failures.

 

 In addition to the accidental release prevention program, our plant has safety features on many units to help (1) quickly detect a release, (2) contain or control a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of or mitigate a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various units of the TDI process:

 

? Release Detection 

 

? Process alarms (e.g., high level alarms and flow cutoff relays on the TDI storage tanks)

? Continuous operator surveillance (e.g., during TDI tanker unloading and TDI supply to the foam process)

 

? Release Containment/Control

 

? Curbing or dikes to contain TDI liquid releases

? TDI storage tanks located inside an enclosed building

? Automated shutdown systems for critical process parameters (e.g., high pressure)

? Pressure relief devices on equipment to prevent rupture

? Valves to permit isolation of process equipment

? Vapor displaced from storage tanks during unloading is vented through a carbon filter

? Facility personnel in attendance whenever TDI is being transferred from a bulk delivery 

  vessel to storage tanks.

 

? Release Mitigation

 

? Fire suppression and extinguishing systems

? Contracted trained emergency response personnel

? Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing 

  apparatus)

 

 Five-year accident history

 

 The facility has not had any releases of TDI in the last 5 years that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage off site.  

 

 Emergency response program

 

 Our emergency response program is based on the requirements in OSHA's emergency action plan regulation, and EPA's emergency response program requirements in its RMP rule.  Our program includes procedures for responding to a relea

se of TDI.  Our procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary, based on modifications made to plant processes or other facilities.  Personnel affected by changes in the program are informed and trained on those changes.

 

 The emergency response plan for the plant is coordinated with the LEPC.  This coordination includes providing them with a copy of the ERP and a subsequent telephone call and invitation to tour the plant.  The plant has around-the-clock communications capability with the appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations such as the fire department.  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.
